awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Collision Prediction and Vehicular Control Using an Episode-Based Modeling Framework
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of the Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) program award is to explore mechanisms for predicting freeway vehicle-to-vehicle collisions and specifying the pre and post-collision maneuvers to improve traffic mobility and safety. This research utilizes concepts from the fields of economics, psychology, and engineering to specify performance measures for traffic system evaluation. In order to realize the research objective, the acceleration and lane-changing driving behaviors that lead to freeway vehicle-to-vehicle collisions will be modeled. A stochastic episode-based framework will be adopted where the driving experience is represented by a series of episodes. Within each episode, a driver accelerates/decelerates in order to maximize his/her preferences and this is represented by a subjective utility function. This function captures risky behavior and collisions. Once collisions occur, another function representing vehicle dynamics will be used to capture the vehicular post-collision movements. The resulting model that integrates the driver's preferences along with vehicle dynamics will be calibrated in real-time using data collected through an instrumented vehicle, a 3-D driving simulator, and a virtual laboratory environment. A simulation tool will be developed to test different pre and post-collision maneuvers that potentially lead to safer and more efficient freeway traffic networks.

If successful, the research will help in the development of different passive and active driving assistance systems. The objective of these systems will be to increase driver's responsiveness and to provide a safer driving environment especially for younger drivers. For this reason, high-school and university students in the Greater Washington Metropolitan Area will be involved in the data-collection and educational activities. Traffic safety workshops will be organized. A virtual interactive 3-D environment will be utilized in these workshops while collaborating with local agencies including the National Children's Museum.

por.por_cntn:
Traffic safety is a very complex topic that requires a better understanding of driving behavior and vehicle dynamics. In an effort to achieve such understanding, this project aims at using a hazard-based modeling framework to predict collisions and control vehicles to achieve a safer freeway traffic environment. The main objectives of the project are:  i) to model the acceleration and lane-changing driving behaviors that lead to freeway vehicle-to-vehicle collisions; ii) to tailor an existing moment-based vehicle dynamics model that capture the vehicular post-collision movements given  different collision impact characteristics; iii) to increase drivers’ responsiveness to different in-vehicle warning messages given some estimated crash related losses; and iv) to simulate different pre-collision and post-collision maneuvers that lead to safer and more efficient freeway traffic networks. The researchers involved in the project have been able to accomplish the following research objectives: i) to model the acceleration and the lane-changing driving behaviors that lead to freeway vehicle-to-vehicle collisions along with tailoring an existing momentum-based post-collision vehicular dynamic and the incorporation of the simplistic collision module as well as connected (i.e. different collision warning system) and automated vehicle modules; ii) to test the corresponding newly formed driver behavioral model in terms of its ability to capture all congestion dynamics; and iii) to calibrate and validate the resulting integrated hybrid model using data collected through a modified driving simulator and  with the involvement of young drivers (i.e. high-school and university students constituting human subjects). 

The developed model is translated into a traffic simulation tool. Different traffic conditions with different speed ranges are simulated and collisions are reproduced.  The associated mobility and safety output are transformed to Collision Involvement Rates (CIRs). Results from the simulation, when compared to data gathered from different highway sections in the United States and South Korea, did not produce identical CIRs; such differences are expected given the stochastic nature of collision formation/dynamics.  However, the total observed/simulated rates were similar in magnitude for both angled collisions (including side-swipe collisions) and rear-end collisions. Focusing on the young drivers (ages 15 – 23), different collision warning systems were tested. The auditory warning only scenario yielded higher rear-end and angled collision CIRs if compared to the no-warning scenario. Audio warning alone may cause confusion among young drivers leading to more behavioral errors. As for the remaining scenarios, even though effectiveness of the tested warnings differs slightly between the tested groups (teenager vs. non-teenager and high school vs. college students), the auditory with informative alphanumeric and the auditory with non-informative symbolic warnings appear to have lower reaction times and lead to fewer collisions than the other tested warning types. This result can be very helpful for both traffic management and automotive manufacturers since the incorporation of such warning systems could help reduce the collisions for one of the most vulnerable driving populations. In particular, the auditory with informative alphanumeric warning seems to lead to a safer response from non-teenage college students; such group of drivers may process more detailed information with an appropriate response time. The auditory with non-informative symbolic warning seems to lead to a safer response from teenage high school students who may consider alphanumeric information distracting and thus causing unsafe behavior.

In conclusion, micro-economics and hazard-based behavioral models can be translated into efficient stochastic traffic simulation tools.  With a proper data collection and simulation set-up, realistic collision involvement rates can be reproduced as a function of the driving population characteristics and the surrounding vehicle and roadway environment. This project shows that more information and more advancement in warning provision systems/technologies do not necessarily lead to safer traffic. Warnings should be tailored to each driver as a function of his/her driver history and his/her physiological and socio-economic characteristics.
